user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

Dear ___,

I am writing to provide a summary of your hospital stay from March 1, 2024, to March 6, 2024, at our facility, following your admission for an acute myocardial infarction.

On March 1, 2024, you were admitted to the hospital due to severe chest pain radiating to your left arm, accompanied by shortness of breath. Upon evaluation, an electrocardiogram (ECG) confirmed the presence of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Immediately thereafter, you underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with the placement of a coronary stent to restore perfusion to the affected area of your heart.

Following the procedure, your condition remained stable, with no recurrence of chest pain, and your vital signs were consistently monitored. On the day of admission, laboratory tests indicated an elevated troponin level, which peaked approximately 12 hours later, consistent with myocardial injury. Your lipid profile revealed elevated LDL cholesterol.

Over the course of your hospital stay, your condition progressively improved. By March 2, 2024, your troponin levels began to decline, indicating a favorable response to treatment, and you reported feeling better with effective pain management. On March 3, 2024, we noted significant improvement during the ward rounds, as preparations for your discharge and subsequent rehabilitation commenced.

Throughout your stay, you received medications including Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and IV Heparin, along with Nitroglycerin for chest pain as needed. Additionally, from March 2, 2024, you were prescribed a beta-blocker, Metoprolol, an ACE inhibitor, Lisinopril, and a statin for cholesterol management.

Upon discharge on March 6, 2024, your condition is noted as stable with no further chest pain episodes, and your vital signs are within normal limits. You have been thoroughly briefed on your medication regimen and lifestyle modifications. It is crucial for you to adopt a heart-healthy diet, gradually reintroduce physical activity, and cease smoking to enhance your cardiovascular health.

A follow-up appointment has been scheduled with the cardiology outpatient clinic for March 20, 2024, to evaluate your recovery progress and review your medication regimen. We recommend you adhere strictly to the prescribed lifestyle changes and report any concerns or symptoms to your healthcare provider promptly.

For any further guidance or in case of emergencies, please contact our department or your primary physician.

Wishing you a steady recovery and continued good health.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___  
Cardiology Department  
[Hospital Name]
